utterances: Well, I'm tiny, actually.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Listen, one thing I love about this is I lived in D.C.

for years, and I was just talking to a friend of mine who also lives in a smallish apartment right in D.C., and she said to me, well, at this point, we're just using my place as, well, a staging area.
(Soundbite of laughing)
What do you do when, first of all, if you're on the receiving end of these self invitations and requests, Amy?

Well, what I love was Veronica's roommate, according to Veronica's essay, which I read and really enjoyed, her roommate actually said to the relative who had basically announced that she was coming to stay, I think the roommate just said, no, that's not going to happen.
I mean, when people are so bold, you get to match their boldness by being very, very direct.
And also Veronica, you know, and her roommate set a nice precedent by letting people stay there who had bothered to ask.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That was the important - yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, prioritize who you're going to let in, maybe, on that basis.

But Amy, if people around the other side, you know, sort of awkwardly going over to the phone and digging up somebody's phone number from some really old phonebook that they've had in their dresser drawer for, you know, seven years now, how do you go about making that suggestion that maybe you could stay over at their house?
(Soundbite of laughter)
What I really like is the idea of - hello - asking, you know, and I think it's OK to pick up the phone and say, look, you know, it's been awhile; how you doing?
Blah, blah, blah; do you still live in D.C.? And if so, I'm thinking about trying to come to the inauguration, and do you have any ideas where I might stay?
You know, I mean, just be very open about it.
That's fine because it's - you know, if you are, then it's easy enough for somebody to say, you know, I don't have a place, but let me look around.
I might know some - I mean, I have a friend who is renting her house for an ungodly sum of money to people.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I mean, you know, there's, like, money to be made here.
Veronica, is that happening?
Renting out our house?
Yeah.
No, because we don't have the rooms, and I would like to stay in my bed.
I have no place else to go that weekend.
There is that.
(Soundbite of laughter)
There is that awkward moment Amy, you know, somebody calls and - well, that extra room I used to have, that's now filled with my twins, who are seven years old.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right, exactly.
But you know what?
That's good.
I mean, one thing I really like about Veronica's behavior through this is she's just being very, very straightforward with all of these people who are being quite assuming, you know?
Let's get some callers in on the conversation, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And Jody is on the line from Denver.
Hi.
CONAN.
Hi, Jody.
You know, after Obama was elected, I emailed a good friend of mine from graduate school who lives in D.C.
now with her family, seeing if I could invite myself over, and she was very gracious, but said she already had 20 people staying in her home, eight of which were under the age of eight.
It sounds like, Jody, you probably didn't want to stay there.
(Soundbite of laughter)
She said we were welcome to come on up any other time, but just not during the inauguration.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And that's thing, isn't it?
Sometimes it's not necessary to people who live here being mean or rude.
It's just they're already - we're already booked up, to say, if you can book a couch.
I have a friend that actually lives in Silver Spring, which is about 15 minutes up the street from here.
And she has eight people that have already signed up to stay in her place.
It's going to look like, you know, a shelter for those couple of days.
Bunk-bed sales must be going through the roof.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Jody, did you find another place to stay?

You know, I decided that it was better just to sit on my nice, comfy couch and watch via the television, because I also have a 14-month-old that I didn't really feel like schlepping down to the Mall to be able to watch.
What's interesting, too, is that, you know, living here in Colorado during the DNC, a lot of people made quite a bit of money by renting out their house.
And we recommend, in fact, you turn on the TV and turn off the sound and turn up the radio.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Agreed.
Will do.
OK, Jody.
Thanks very much.

Here is a one from - an email from Nicole in Baltimore: I had an ex-boyfriend who couldn't even find my contact information.
He had to contact me via my MySpace account to ask me if he and his new girlfriend could come and stay at our house.
Amy, that's seems a little beyond the pale.

I mean, he's not even a very good ex.
